qas.question: What may servo motors be used for?

answers.text: machine tools, pen plotters, and other process systems

qas.question: What must be well understood when applying a servo motor for use?
What factors limit performance of servo motors?
Large, slow servos can use what types of motors?
When might coreless motors be used in servo applications?

plausible_answers.text: machine tools, pen plotters, and other process systems

qas.question: What may servo motors never be used for?
What must not be well understood when applying a servo motor for use?
What factors don't limit performance of servo motors?
Small, fast servos can use what types of motors?

context: A servomotor is a motor, very often sold as a complete module, which is used within a position-control or speed-control feedback control system mainly control valves, such as motor-operated control valves. Servomotors are used in applications such as <a0_0><b5_0>machine tools, pen plotters, and other process systems<b5_0/><a0_0/>. Motors intended for use in a servomechanism must have well-documented characteristics for <a1_0><b6_0>speed, torque, and power<b6_0/><a1_0/>. The speed vs. torque curve is quite important and is high ratio for a servo motor. Dynamic response characteristics such as <a2_0><b7_0>winding inductance and rotor inertia<b7_0/><a2_0/> are also important; these factors limit the overall performance of the servomechanism loop. Large, powerful, but slow-responding servo loops may use <a3_0><b8_0>conventional AC or DC motors<b8_0/><a3_0/> and drive systems with position or speed feedback on the motor. <a4_0>As dynamic response requirements increase<a4_0/>, more specialized motor designs such as coreless motors are used. AC motors' superior power density and acceleration characteristics compared to that of DC motors tends to favor PM synchronous, BLDC, induction, and SRM drive applications.
